elements.content: The substitution reactions of M(CH3CH2CO2)2 and Htza afford the crystalline precipitates of [Cd(tza)2] (1), [Mn(tza)2] (2), [Co(tza)2] (3), and β-[Zn(tza)2] (5). The recrystallization of 5 leads to the formation of α-[Zn(tza)2] (4). X-ray powder diffraction of 1−5 reveal that 1, 2, 3, and 5 are allomers, but 4 and 5 are isomers, revealing the unprecedented structural transformation during the process of recrystallization. Compounds 1−4 have been characterized by X-ray single-crystal crystallography, IR, and magnetism analysis. Structural analyses and comparison of 1−4 detail the structural evolution of from β-[Zn(tza)2] (5) to α-[Zn(tza)2] (4) and possible driving force has been proposed. The interactions between the MnII ions of 2 have been observed as weakly antiferromagnetic.

elements.content: Chemical reactions usually produce noncrystalline or polycrystalline products that are not suitable for crystal structure analyses. Recrystallization is one of the most widely and effectively used methods to prepare single crystals for structural determination of reaction products with the belief of the fact that single crystals obtained from recrystallization usually have a crystal structure similar to that of the precursors. However, in the cases of fast reactions that are usually driven by the low solubility of the products, the crystal structures of the products are not always the dynamically most stable. Furthermore, solvents used for recrystallization are also different from those in preparative reactions. As a consequence, the isomerization or structural transformation of the products might occur in the process of recrystallization, which usually leads to the formation of the dynamically most stable structure. Differing from crystal-to-crystal structural transition, which is usually induced by thermal treatment, racemization photochemical excitation, and involves cooperative movement of atoms in the solid state, recrystallization-induced structural transformation is more likely caused by the dynamic factors or structural stability such as coordination geometry requirements. However, the reported examples detailing such recrystallization-induced structural transformation are extremely rare, although different reaction routes have been reported to produce polymorphs. Our knowledge about how structural transformation occurs in the process of recrystallization and driving force is very limited. In this work, the fast polymerization reactions of M(CH3CH2CO2)2 (M = Zn, Cd, Mn, Co) and Htza produce the polycrystalline precipitates of [M(tza)2]. Recrystallization has been used to get the suitable single crystals of [Cd(tza)2] (1), [Mn(tza)2] (2), [Co(tza)2] (3), and [Zn(tza)2] (4). The unprecedented structural transformation in the case of [Zn(tza)2] has been observed, as will be detailed.(Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chemical reactions usually produce noncrystalline or polycrystalline products that are not suitable for crystal structure analyses. Recrystallization is one of the most widely and effectively used methods to prepare single crystals for structural determination of reaction products with the belief of the fact that single crystals obtained from recrystallization usually have a crystal structure similar to that of the precursors. However, in the cases of fast reactions that are usually driven by the low solubility of the products, the crystal structures of the products are not always the dynamically most stable. Furthermore, solvents used for recrystallization are also different from those in preparative reactions. As a consequence, the isomerization or structural transformation of the products might occur in the process of recrystallization, which usually leads to the formation of the dynamically most stable structure. Differing from crystal-to-crystal structural transition, which is usually induced by thermal treatment, racemization photochemical excitation, and involves cooperative movement of atoms in the solid state, recrystallization-induced structural transformation is more likely caused by the dynamic factors or structural stability such as coordination geometry requirements. However, the reported examples detailing such recrystallization-induced structural transformation are extremely rare, although different reaction routes have been reported to produce polymorphs. Our knowledge about how structural transformation occurs in the process of recrystallization and driving force is very limited. In this work, the fast polymerization reactions of M(CH3CH2CO2)2 (M = Zn, Cd, Mn, Co) and Htza produce the polycrystalline precipitates of [M(tza)2]. Recrystallization has been used to get the suitable single crystals of [Cd(tza)2] (1), [Mn(tza)2] (2), [Co(tza)2] (3), and [Zn(tza)2] (4). The unprecedented structural transformation in the case of [Zn(tza)2] has been observed, as will be detailed.(Figure ).

elements.content: Tetrazoles and its derivatives have been widely used as polyfunctional ligands because of the aromaticity and multiple coordinating modes. Very recently, N-substituted tetrazolate ligands have received increasing attention because of the low-temperature ferromagnetism and thermal spin-state transition of their metal complexes. A series of CuII or FeII complexes of 1-substituted tetrazoles (1-R-tetrazoles), R = alkyl, phenyl, chloroethyl, and methoxyethyl were found to be a new type of low-temperature ferromagnetism or thermal spin-state transition. Unfortunately, all of these complexes have low-dimensional structures because the unfunctionalized N-monosubstituents show no coordination ability and thus disfavor the formation of higher-dimensional structures. With this concern in mind, N-carboxylated derivative, tetrazole-1-acetic acid, was selected for the following several considerations: (i) The additional strong coordinating ability of carboxylate arms is expected to exhibit more varied coordinating patterns in the construction of coordination frameworks. (ii) The −CH2− spacer between the tetrazole ring and CO2 donor group offers flexible orientations of the carboxylate arm, favoring the formation of varied framework structures. As expected, the substitution reactions of M(CH3CH2CO2)2 and Htza afford the polycrystalline precipitates of [Cd(tza)2] (1), [Mn(tza)2] (2), [Co(tza)2] (3), and β-[Zn(tza)2] (5). The recrystallization of 5 leads to the formation of the isomeric α-[Zn(tza)2] (4) with quite distinct structure from that of β-[Zn(tza)2] (5). Their crystal structures, structural transformation, and magnetic properties will be detailed in this work.

Very recently, N-substituted tetrazolate ligands have received increasing attention because of the low-temperature ferromagnetism and thermal spin-state transition of their metal complexes. A series of CuII or FeII complexes of 1-substituted tetrazoles (1-R-tetrazoles), R = alkyl, phenyl, chloroethyl, and methoxyethyl were found to be a new type of low-temperature ferromagnetism or thermal spin-state transition. Unfortunately, all of these complexes have low-dimensional structures because the unfunctionalized N-monosubstituents show no coordination ability and thus disfavor the formation of higher-dimensional structures. With this concern in mind, N-carboxylated derivative, tetrazole-1-acetic acid, was selected for the following several considerations: (i) The additional strong coordinating ability of carboxylate arms is expected to exhibit more varied coordinating patterns in the construction of coordination frameworks. (ii) The -CH2- spacer between the tetrazole ring and CO2 donor group offers flexible orientations of the carboxylate arm, favoring the formation of varied framework structures. As expected, the substitution reactions of M(CH3CH2CO2)2 and Htza afford the polycrystalline precipitates of [Cd(tza)2] (1), [Mn(tza)2] (2), [Co(tza)2] (3), and β-[Zn(tza)2] (5). The recrystallization of 5 leads to the formation of the isomeric α-[Zn(tza)2] (4) with quite distinct structure from that of β-[Zn(tza)2] (5). Their crystal structures, structural transformation, and magnetic properties will be detailed in this work.

elements.content: Tetrazole-1-acetic acid was synthesized in accordance with a published procedure. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the 4000−400 cm−1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractormeter using Cu Kα radiation. Variable-temperature (2.0−300.0 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS60000 in a magnetic field of 5000 Oe, and the diamagnetic corrections were evaluated using Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Tetrazole-1-acetic acid was synthesized in accordance with a published procedure. All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a PANalytical X'Pert Pro diffractormeter using Cu Kα radiation. Variable-temperature (2.0-300.0 K) magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS60000 in a magnetic field of 5000 Oe, and the diamagnetic corrections were evaluated using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of complexes 1−4 were mounted on a Rigaku Mercury-CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All absorption corrections were performed using the CrystalClear programs. Structures were solved by the direct-methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXTL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds 1−4 are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond length parameters are summarized in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Single-Crystal Determination

Suitable single crystals of complexes 1-4 were mounted on a Rigaku Mercury-CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All absorption corrections were performed using the CrystalClear programs. Structures were solved by the direct-methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELXTL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. Hydrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions. Crystallographic data and structural refinements for compounds 1-4 are summarized in Table 1. The selected bond length parameters are summarized in Table 2.

elements.content: The substitution reactions of M(CH3COO)2 with Htza in methanol or ethanol at room temperature in the molar ratio 1:2 afford good yield of white polycrystalline precipitates of the M-tza polymers [M(tza)2]∞. The crystalline precipitates of Zn, Cd, Mn, and Co exhibit the similar X-ray powder diffraction patterns, suggesting that they are isostructural. Their single crystals of high quality were obtained from a mixture of MeOH/H2O at room temperature The measured and calculated XRD patterns of 1 (2 or 3) march perfectly as expected, indicating that the precipitate is pure and the solid structure keeps unchanged during crystallization process (Figure ). Interestingly, the calculated XRD pattern of the recrystallized product, namely α-Zn(tza)2 (4), is remarkably different from that of the precursor β-Zn(tza)2 (5), suggestive of the occurrence of the structural change during the recryctallization process. It is not clear why the α-Zn(tza)2 (4) can not be formed directly from the preparative reaction although the absence of water, which is used for recrystallization, in the reaction system may be one of the causes. Comparable examples are the two polymorphs of [tetCo(NO 2 ) 2 ]NO 3 that differ in the sense of the relative orientation two trans-NO2 planes (ca. 0 and 90°, respectively) and the coordination geometry of the Co3+ ion remains unchanged. They were obtained from two different reaction approaches ([Co(NO2)6]3− + tet and [tetCoCl2] + 2NO2 −) but the same solvent (water). These observations indicate that reaction products are closely related to the preparative routes.(Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Preparation of Compounds 1-5 

The substitution reactions of M(CH3COO)2 with Htza in methanol or ethanol at room temperature in the molar ratio 1:2 afford good yield of white polycrystalline precipitates of the M-tza polymers [M(tza)2]∞. The crystalline precipitates of Zn, Cd, Mn, and Co exhibit the similar X-ray powder diffraction patterns, suggesting that they are isostructural. Their single crystals of high quality were obtained from a mixture of MeOH/H2O at room temperature The measured and calculated XRD patterns of 1 (2 or 3) march perfectly as expected, indicating that the precipitate is pure and the solid structure keeps unchanged during crystallization process (Figure ). Interestingly, the calculated XRD pattern of the recrystallized product, namely α-Zn(tza)2 (4), is remarkably different from that of the precursor β-Zn(tza)2 (5), suggestive of the occurrence of the structural change during the recryctallization process. It is not clear why the α-Zn(tza)2 (4) can not be formed directly from the preparative reaction although the absence of water, which is used for recrystallization, in the reaction system may be one of the causes. Comparable examples are the two polymorphs of [tetCo(NO  2  )  2  ]NO  3  that differ in the sense of the relative orientation two trans-NO2 planes (ca. 0 and 90°, respectively) and the coordination geometry of the Co3+ ion remains unchanged. They were obtained from two different reaction approaches ([Co(NO2)6]3- + tet and [tetCoCl2] + 2NO2 -) but the same solvent (water). These observations indicate that reaction products are closely related to the preparative routes.(Table ).

Compounds 1, 2, and 3 crystallize in monoclinic space group P21/n with the metal center lying on the crystallographic inversion center (Figure ). The cadmium(II) atom possesses distorted octahedral coordination geometry with the equatorial positions occupied by the carboxylate oxygens donors and the apical ones taken up by the tza nitrogen atoms from the surrounding six different tza ligands. The N−Cd−O angles range from 79.79(7) to 100.21(7)°, revealing the seriously distorted octahedron with the equatorial Cd−O distances of 2.260(2) and 2.312(2) Å and the apical Cd−N of 2.339 (2) Å (Table ). The Cd atoms are bridged by the carboxylate groups into infinite chains as shown in Figure a in syn−anti mode I (Figure ), which differs from the reported bridging mode II (Figure ) to form a Cd2C2O4 eight-membered ring. The infinite chains are arranged in such a way that they are be able to be interconnected via the apical coordination the N atom trans to the carxoxylate arm resulting in a X-like 3D framework structure (Figure b) of (4261083)(4162)2 topology (Figure ) with the tza rings are almost parallel to ach other. The center-to-center distances of greater than 4 Å reveal the insignificant π-stacking interactions. It is interest to note that [Cd(ima)2] (Hima = 2-(1-H-imidazole-1-yl)acetate) with similar coordinating mode of ima adopts 2D layered structure probably as a consequence of the fact that the Cd center has a rather regular octahedral coordination geometry instead of the distorted one presented here.

Crystal Structures [M(tza)2] (1, M = Cd; 2, M = Mn; 3, M = Co)

Compounds 1, 2, and 3 crystallize in monoclinic space group P21/n with the metal center lying on the crystallographic inversion center (Figure ). The cadmium(II) atom possesses distorted octahedral coordination geometry with the equatorial positions occupied by the carboxylate oxygens donors and the apical ones taken up by the tza nitrogen atoms from the surrounding six different tza ligands. The N-Cd-O angles range from 79.79(7) to 100.21(7)°, revealing the seriously distorted octahedron with the equatorial Cd-O distances of 2.260(2) and 2.312(2) Å and the apical Cd-N of 2.339 (2) Å (Table ). The Cd atoms are bridged by the carboxylate groups into infinite chains as shown in Figure a in syn-anti mode I (Figure ), which differs from the reported bridging mode II (Figure ) to form a Cd2C2O4 eight-membered ring. The infinite chains are arranged in such a way that they are be able to be interconnected via the apical coordination the N atom trans to the carxoxylate arm resulting in a X-like 3D framework structure (Figure b) of (4261083)(4162)2 topology (Figure ) with the tza rings are almost parallel to ach other. The center-to-center distances of greater than 4 Å reveal the insignificant π-stacking interactions. It is interest to note that [Cd(ima)2] (Hima = 2-(1-H-imidazole-1-yl)acetate) with similar coordinating mode of ima adopts 2D layered structure probably as a consequence of the fact that the Cd center has a rather regular octahedral coordination geometry instead of the distorted one presented here.

elements.content: As mentioned above, β-[Zn(tza)2] (5) has a similar structure to that of 1, 2, and 3. It is converted intoα-[Zn(tza)2] 4 with the space group C2/c in the process of recrystallization. The following structural comparison of 1−4 enables us to understand how structural transformation occurs during recrystallization.
elements.clean_text:
[Zn(tza)2] (4, 5)

As mentioned above, β-[Zn(tza)2] (5) has a similar structure to that of 1, 2, and 3. It is converted intoα-[Zn(tza)2] 4 with the space group C2/c in the process of recrystallization. The following structural comparison of 1-4 enables us to understand how structural transformation occurs during recrystallization.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the ZnII atom lying on the crystallographic 2-fold axis has similar octahedral coordination geometry to that of the CdII and MnII analogues with the equatorial Zn−O bond lengths of 2.086(2) and 2.108(2) Å and the apical Zn−N distances of 2.184(2) Å. However, the distortion is much less serious in the case of α-[Zn(tza)2] (4). The N−Zn−O angles of 86.78(7)−93.26(7)° are closer to 90° as compared with those of 1 (79.79(7)−100.21(7)°), 2 (81.90(5)−98.10(8)°), and Co (82.48(10)−97.52(10)°), indicating that the ZnO4N2 octahedron is more regular. With these comparisons in mind, we assume that the regular octahedral coordination requirement of the [Zn(tza)2] is one of the important driving forces in β- to α-transformation in the process of recrystallization.

However, the distortion is much less serious in the case of α-[Zn(tza)2] (4). With these comparisons in mind, we assume that the regular octahedral coordination requirement of the [Zn(tza)2] is one of the important driving forces in β- to α-transformation in the process of recrystallization.

elements.content: As in the case of 1 (or 2, 3), the tza ligand with the similar syn−anti tridentate coordination mode (Figure ) links the Zn atoms into an infinite chain through the carboxylate groups featuring the Zn2C2O4 8-membered rings, which is further interconnected by the apical ligation of the tetrazole nitrogen atoms into a so-called rod-based framework structure of (446288101)(4261)2 topology as displayed in Figure . However, the above-mentioned remarkable difference in the coordination geometry results in their distinct space groups and thus different crystal structures. (i) The orientation of the apical tza planes with dihedral angles of 0° in 1 (or 2 and 3) but 90° in 4 as required by the crystallographically imposed symmetry. (ii) As shown in Figures a and a, the bridging carboxylate groups have two kinds of up and down orientations that appear alternatively in the Zn−CO2 chain of 4, but only one is observed in 1. (iii) As a consequence, the linkage ways between the metal chains are quite different. The apical tza ligands of each metal chain in 1 (or 2 and 3) connect only one neighboring metal chain to form a single-X architecture (Figure b; X is overlapped). However, the up and down orientations of the RCO2 groups in 4 make the apical tza ligands to connect two neighboring octahedral Zn chains to form a double-X structure (Figure b; X is displaced).

elements.content: Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 2 over the range 2−300 K has been measured in a field of 5000 Oe. μeff and χm vs T plot are shown in the . μeff decreases from 5.81 μB at 234.4 K, which is close to the spin-only value for magnetically isolated high-spin MnII, to 2.19 μB at 2.0 K, indicative of an antiferromagnetic spin exchange between the two high-spin MnII centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of 2 

Temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of 2 over the range 2-300 K has been measured in a field of 5000 Oe. μeff and χm vs T plot are shown in the . μeff decreases from 5.81 μB at 234.4 K, which is close to the spin-only value for magnetically isolated high-spin MnII, to 2.19 μB at 2.0 K, indicative of an antiferromagnetic spin exchange between the two high-spin MnII centers.

elements.content: The Fisher chain model (eq ) has been used to get the best fit to the measured χm. χ m = [ Ng 2 β S ( S + 1 ) 3 k B T ] [ 1 + μ 1 − μ ] Where μ = cot [ JS ( S + 1 ) k B T ] − [ k B T JS ( S + 1 ) ] The best fit was obtained for J = −0.666 cm−1 and g = 1.99133 with the convergence factor of 1.6 × 10−4. The small J reveals weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the MnII ions as in the case of reported carboxylato-bridged Mn species (−0.2 to −2 cm−1).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as shown in the , were performed for compounds 2−5 to examine their stability. Both α-Zn(tza)2 (4) and β-Zn(tza)2 (5) are stable up to ca. 185 °C and then collapse, presumably because of the decomposition of tza ligand to N3 and CNCCO2 (calcd, 73.7%; found, 75.7%). Mn(tza)2 (2) and Co(tza)2 (3) are slightly more stable up to 220 °C and decompose similar to the case of Zn(tza)2. β-Zn(tza)2 (5) loses the organic ligand to form ZnO at a much lower temperature (ca. 600 °C) than α-Zn(tza)2 (4) (900 °C; calcd, 25.3%; found, 25.1%). Co(tza)2 (3) loses the organic liagnd to give CoO (calcd, 23.9%; found, 22.0%) as in the case of the Zn analogues,but Mn(tza)2 (2) finally decomposes to produce MnO2 (calcd, 28.1%; found, 33.7%).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as shown in the , were performed for compounds 2-5 to examine their stability. Both α-Zn(tza)2 (4) and β-Zn(tza)2 (5) are stable up to ca. 185 °C and then collapse, presumably because of the decomposition of tza ligand to N3 and CNCCO2 (calcd, 73.7%; found, 75.7%). Mn(tza)2 (2) and Co(tza)2 (3) are slightly more stable up to 220 °C and decompose similar to the case of Zn(tza)2. β-Zn(tza)2 (5) loses the organic ligand to form ZnO at a much lower temperature (ca. 600 °C) than α-Zn(tza)2 (4) (900 °C; calcd, 25.3%; found, 25.1%). Co(tza)2 (3) loses the organic liagnd to give CoO (calcd, 23.9%; found, 22.0%) as in the case of the Zn analogues,but Mn(tza)2 (2) finally decomposes to produce MnO2 (calcd, 28.1%; found, 33.7%).

elements.content: Although the recrystallized products usually have structures similar to those of their precursors as in the cases of Cd(tza)2 (1), Mn(tza)2 (2), and Co(tza)2 (3), the quite distinct structures of β-[Zn(tza)2] (5) and α-[Zn(tza)2] (4) clearly indicate the occurrence of structural transformation in the process of recrystallization. Coordination geometry requirement is one of the important driving forces of such structural changes. These observations suggest that one should be very careful when using structural information of recrystallized products to characterize the reaction products. This work also reveals the potential of the Htza ligand in the construction of high-dimensional structures through additional carboxylate arms.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Although the recrystallized products usually have structures similar to those of their precursors as in the cases of Cd(tza)2 (1), Mn(tza)2 (2), and Co(tza)2 (3), the quite distinct structures of β-[Zn(tza)2] (5) and α-[Zn(tza)2] (4) clearly indicate the occurrence of structural transformation in the process of recrystallization. Coordination geometry requirement is one of the important driving forces of such structural changes. These observations suggest that one should be very careful when using structural information of recrystallized products to characterize the reaction products. This work also reveals the potential of the Htza ligand in the construction of high-dimensional structures through additional carboxylate arms.

Synthesis of [Zn(tza)2] (α-4, β-5)

[Zn(tza)2] was prepared similarly. Htza (0.08 g, 0.6 mmol) in MeOH (3 mL) was added to a stirring methanol (2 mL) solution of Zn(CH3COO)2⋅2H2O (0.066 g, 0.3mmol) at room temperature. The white precipitate of 5 was formed and isolated immediately. The precipitate was dissolved in water (4 mL) and carefully layered with methanol (10 mL). cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as shown in the , were performed for compounds 2−5 to examine their stability. Both α-Zn(tza)2 (4) and β-Zn(tza)2 (5) are stable up to ca. 185 °C and then collapse, presumably because of the decomposition of tza ligand to N3 and CNCCO2 (calcd, 73.7%; found, 75.7%). Mn(tza)2 (2) and Co(tza)2 (3) are slightly more stable up to 220 °C and decompose similar to the case of Zn(tza)2. β-Zn(tza)2 (5) loses the organic ligand to form ZnO at a much lower temperature (ca. 600 °C) than α-Zn(tza)2 (4) (900 °C; calcd, 25.3%; found, 25.1%). Co(tza)2 (3) loses the organic liagnd to give CoO (calcd, 23.9%; found, 22.0%) as in the case of the Zn analogues,but Mn(tza)2 (2) finally decomposes to produce MnO2 (calcd, 28.1%; found, 33.7%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) as shown in the , were performed for compounds 2-5 to examine their stability. Both α-Zn(tza)2 (4) and β-Zn(tza)2 (5) are stable up to ca. 185 °C and then collapse, presumably because of the decomposition of tza ligand to N3 and CNCCO2 (calcd, 73.7%; found, 75.7%). Mn(tza)2 (2) and Co(tza)2 (3) are slightly more stable up to 220 °C and decompose similar to the case of Zn(tza)2. β-Zn(tza)2 (5) loses the organic ligand to form ZnO at a much lower temperature (ca. 600 °C) than α-Zn(tza)2 (4) (900 °C; calcd, 25.3%; found, 25.1%). Co(tza)2 (3) loses the organic liagnd to give CoO (calcd, 23.9%; found, 22.0%) as in the case of the Zn analogues,but Mn(tza)2 (2) finally decomposes to produce MnO2 (calcd, 28.1%; found, 33.7%).
